Techniques for breaking bad financial habits

sections.title: The Science of Habit Formation
sections.content: Habits are automatic behaviors triggered by cues and rewarded by outcomes. Financial habits like automatic saving or regular expense tracking become easier over time. The key is starting small and being consistent rather than trying to change everything at once.

points.title: Daily Tracking
points.description: Review expenses daily to maintain awareness of spending patterns.

points.title: Automatic Saving
points.description: Set up automatic transfers to savings and investment accounts.

points.title: Regular Reviews
points.description: Weekly or monthly financial check-ins to stay on track with goals.

sections.title: Start Small for Big Changes
sections.content: Don't try to overhaul your entire financial life at once. Focus on one or two key habits and build from there. Small, consistent actions compound over time.

sections.title: Breaking Bad Financial Habits
sections.content: Identify triggers for bad habits and replace them with positive alternatives. For impulse spending, implement a 24-hour waiting period. Track progress and be patient - old habits die hard but can be replaced with better ones.

sections.title: Build Better Money Habits
steps: Identify one bad financial habit you want to change
Choose a specific, positive habit to replace it
Set up reminders and accountability systems
Track your progress for 30 days and adjust as needed

sections.title: Habit Stacking
sections.content: Link new financial habits to existing routines. For example, review your budget while having your morning coffee or save money every time you get paid.
